body.p: Examination of Allen Wilhoit Made at his house, Boone County Ky Sept 10th 1861
Question 1st Did you examine James Landrum, at your house, on the morning of the 9th Jan 1858, and take from his pocket book Eighteen dollars & 40 cents,
Answer He was searched here, but I do not remember the day and the moth, about that amount was taken from his pocket book

Question 2nd The said sak Sasher swore on the 21st day of Feb of the same year in his complaint before a Justice of the peace in Boone County that said Landrum, had stolen and Carried away from your house the above named amount, now did you not, on the morning of the 9th day of Jan above named give up to said Sasher the Eighteen dollars & forty cents, which you took from Landrum, in presence of Landrum & others

Answer
I think that Landrum gave the money up to Sasher & go out and told me to go out to Sasher & compromise the matter with him, by giving him up part of the money and if he would not do that, to give him all

3rd Question At the examination held before the Justices did you not hear Sasher Swear, that
on the day of the night He said Sasher in which he alledged that he was robbed by said Landrum he the said Sasher left Covington, and had on his person but $300 or $3,25, and if so did not Sasher make the statement under oath, did we not hear the Counsel in the pleadings make this statement, as having as has been sworn to before by the said Sasher, without denial or objection, on the part of Sasher or his Counsel and if you did hear this, how could you subsequently go before the Grand jury, and aid in procuring and indictment against said Landrum for stealing $18.40 from a man who admitted under oath that he had in his possession but $300 or $3,40

Answer, I was not present at the time or in the room at the time that Sasher gave his evidence, but I heard Sasher say the amt and kind of money he had lost, at at the examination of Landrum that Amount was found, and in the kind of money that Sasher claimed to have lost

4th Question
Are you not a strong personal eney enemy of Grubbs; and have you some very Slanderous & villainous charge against his character in the presence of Moses Rice, Kennett & others?
6th Question. Are you not an avowed personal enemy of the said Grubb's? Ans, I am no enymy enemy to him, I am no enemy to any one.
7th Ques. Did you see anyone, and if so whom give to Sasher, on the morning of the search the $18.40
Ans, No I did not see any one give him the money
Lucinda Willhoit
Mr. Haggerty
Dr Sir: Please see to it that at the examination Mrs & Mr Wilhoit be not present at other examinations as this is not a civil case
Yours Wm Grubbs

This may certify that I Albert Stephens a justice of the peace for Boone County had the foregoing questions propounded to the above subscribed Lucinda Wilhoit, after having swore her to answer twenty such questions as might be propounded to her, and her answers were reduced to writing in my presence and signed by her as witness my hand this 10th day of September 1861
Albert Stephens J P B C
Examination of Mrs. Wilhoit

1st Question Did James Landrum give you his pocket-book on the morning of the 9th of January 1858, which it is alleged contained the money that the said Landrum was accused of stealing from William Sasher on the preceeding night? Ans He never gave it me

2nd Question Did the said Landrum on handing you the pocket-book request you to give the money alleged to have been stolen to the said Sasher and to say to him that he the said Landrum took it when he was drunk and did not know at the time what he was doing? I never heard that said
3rd Question Were not some such declaration as thoese made by you to lawyers Armstrong or Rankins

4th Question Were not some such declarations at the above made by you, and were they not made for the purpose of having them reported to the accused Lundrum with the intent to intimidate him, and drive him off, hereby causing him to forfeit his bail, and for the express purpose of compelling his surities to suffer? Ans, No.

5th Question. Did you never express to some of your female neighbors the wish that the accused Landrum would run off, so that his surety Grubbs would have his bail to pay as he was the only responsible one of said Landrum's Surities? Ans I do not recollect that I ever expressed any wish about it
